title: Between 1 July 2019 and 30 June 2020, will an armed group from South Sudan engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in South Sudan?
preds: I updated my estimation after looking past year resolution and understanding what the meaning of the question really is.
Want to make another prediction now that situation has changed and citizens are becoming more and more active in putting effort to not have such killings anymore.

During the last eight years we had the Ubor and Pibor massacres, 640 and 900 victims respectively (for the second I use the UN estimates). Now, the probability of killings follows an inverse power law distribution with an exponent of 2.5. 1) If I use Ubor as a baseline for the period 2011-2019, then there have been two 640+ events in the last 8 years and the probability of a 1000+ massacre will be about 33% that of a 640 one. This yields a 2/8 times 0.33 probability of 1000+ per year: 8.2% 2) If I use Pibor as a baseline, the probability of a 1000+ killing is about 77% of that of a 900 killing. This yiels 1/8 times 0.77 probability of 1000+ per year: 9.6 % 3) The average is 8.9% per year and there are 9.5 months till the dealine, so we end up with a 7% probability. Really high.
Current fighting around for example Aweil will likely (continue to) include attacks on villages and forced displacement.

Violence is decreasing overall, but attacks on civilians are still high in some regions and it is unclear how stable the peace agreement is. Civilian deaths are ongoing, but may not reach 1000 for any one group https://www.voanews.com/africa/un-more-100-civilians-killed-fresh-s-sudan-violence
